title: Advanced Diploma in Managerial Skills for Interpersonal Dynamics
headline: Free online course on managerial skills development and the components of interpersonal dynamics at the workplace.
description: This free online managerial skills for interpersonal dynamics course provides a comprehensive guide on how to build, maintain, and repair relationships in the workplace for effective performance. Learn how to be happy at work as well as the positive effect of using humor at the workplace. Learn also how to manage your moods and emotions so as to enhance synergy at work. Begin this course today and improve your interpersonal communication skills.

courseDescription:
This free online Managerial skills for Interpersonal Dynamics course will begin by introducing you to the tenets of relationship development, conflict resolution and relationship maintenance. You will also be introduced to the fundamentals of interpersonal relationships which include employees behaviour, their ability to forgive one another, the role recognition plays in motivating employees, as well as the ability of individual employees to take ownership of their contributions for the overall achievement of the organization's goals.
This course will then introduce you to the core of managerial effectiveness, and how it can be applied in the workplace. You will learn about the effect of optimism on employees' productivity. You will also learn how career engagement is pivotal to the success of an organization. Then, you will learn how employee involvement can increase their level of engagement as well as their performance on the job, thereby leading to maturity in the workplace.
Furthermore, this course will explain the concept of ego defense mechanisms, group dynamics, and the interaction that occurs between the different groups that make up an organization. This course also sheds light on how to tackle emotional negotiation at work, manage employees' expectations as well as their anger, anxiety, and depression. Finally, learn how quality of life and work enrichment impact on employees' performance and their relationship at the workplace.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this diploma course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this diploma course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison diploma is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital diploma: a downloadable diploma in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked diploma, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked diploma in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All diploma are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison diploma, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison diploma, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our diploma pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Building and Maintaining Relationships at the Workplace
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to the concepts of relationship maintenance, relationship management, as well as the importance of building and maintaining relationships at the workplace. You will also be introduced to the concept of FIRO-B, the evolution of FIRO-B, the different types of behavior as well as the models of FIRO-B.
topics: Building and Maintaining Relationships at the Workplace - Learning Outcomes
Knapp's Ten Stages of a Relationship
Behaviours Associated with Inclusion, Affection, and Control Needs
Building and Maintaining Relationships at the Workplace - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Forgiveness and Happiness at the Workplace
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to the concept and meaning of forgiveness, as well as the dimensions and models of forgiveness. You will also be introduced to the types of forgiveness and the concept of happiness at the workplace. You will learn about the role happiness plays in driving an organization's productivity, theories of happiness, and the key defining characteristics of workplace happiness.
topics: Forgiveness and Happiness at the Workplace - Learning Outcomes
Forgiveness and Happiness at the Workplace - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to the concept of trust and the importance of trust in the workplace. You will learn about the meaning of employee recognition, types of employee recognition, and the effect of employee recognition in the workplace. You will also learn about the importance of psychological ownership, the different dimensions of psychological ownership, and the antecedents of psychological ownership.
topics: Trust and Employee Recognition - Learning Outcomes
Trust and Employee Recognition - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to the concept of managerial effectiveness and servant leadership. You will learn about the ten roles of a manager as propounded by Henry Mintzberg, as well as the six Cs of communication, and how to apply them for effective and efficient management of people. You will then learn about the purpose of leadership and the characteristics of a servant leader.
topics: Managerial Effectiveness and Servant Leadership - Learning Outcomes
Concepts and Models of Managerial Effectiveness
Managerial Effectiveness and Servant Leadership - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to the concept and meaning of moods, emotions, and optimism. You will learn about affect, emotions and moods, the functions of emotions, sources of emotions, and moods. You will also learn how to apply your emotions, moods, frustration, and the different stress coping strategies that can be used to manage them. Then, you will learn about the difference between personal optimism and self-efficacy optimism, as well as the theories of optimism.
topics: Moods, Emotions, and Optimism - Learning Outcomes
The New Model of Moods and Emotions
Moods, Emotions and Optimism - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to the concept of career engagement and adaptability. You will learn why career engagement matters in an organization as well as the difference between career management and career engagement. You will also learn about the adaptability process in an organization, the antecedents of adaptive performance, as well as the concept of distal predictors and conscientiousness.
topics: Career Engagement and Adaptability - Learning Outcomes
Career Engagement: Wheels of Career Engagement
The Antecedents and Enemies of Adaptability
Career Engagement and Adaptability - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Diploma in Managerial Skills for Interpersonal Dynamics - First Assessment
modules.description: You must score 80% or more to pass this assessment.
topics: Diploma in Managerial Skills for Interpersonal Dynamics - First Assessment

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to the meaning of spiritual intelligence. You will learn about the effect of insult on interpersonal relationships and work motivation. You also learn about the role of peace in the achievement of an organization’s purposes. You will then learn about the three psychological needs of every individual.
topics: Spiritual Intelligence and Work Motivation - Learning Outcomes
The Dimensions and Skills of Spiritual Intelligence
Spiritual Intelligence and Work Motivation - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Employee Involvement, Humour and Maturity at Work
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to the concept of employee involvement, humour at the workplace, preparedness and performance, maturity at the workplace, and hope. You will learn about the different levels of employee involvement and the purpose of employee involvement. You will also learn about the two-dimensional models of workplace humour, as well as why mental preparedness is important. You will then learn the Erikson's stages of psychosocial development.
topics: Employee Involvement, Humor and Maturity at Work - Learning Outcomes
Employee Involvement, Humour and Maturity at Work - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Ego Defense Mechanism and Emotional Negotiation
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to the concept of Ego Defense Mechanism and Group Dynamics, dyadic relationships at work, emotional negotiation, anger, anxiety, and depression. You will learn about the different theories of group dynamics and group counseling. You will also learn how to maintain work relationships, as well as the concept of dyadic relationships, the five-step approach for emotional negotiation, and the causes of depression and how it can be treated
topics: Ego Defense Mechanism and Emotional Negotiation - Learning Outcomes
Anxiety and Depression: Causes and Treatment
Ego Defense Mechanism and Emotional Negotiation - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Expectations, Thinking Process and Managerial Flexibility
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to the concept of expectations, thinking process, managerial flexibility, and reinstating relationships. You will learn about the difference between positive and negative aspects of low expectations and the elements of your thought process. You will also learn about the elements of managerial flexibility and the effective ways of resolving relationship problems.
topics: Expectations, Thinking Process and Managerial Flexibility - Learning Outcomes
Expectations, Thinking Process and Managerial Flexibility - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Buddhism, Panchatantra, Bhagwat Gita and Interpersonal Dynamics
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to the concept of the Buddhist approach to managerial skills for interpersonal dynamics. You will learn about the contribution of Panchatantra to the management of Interpersonal relationships. You will also be introduced to the concepts of Emotion, Nutrition, Brain, the influence of Bhagwat Gita on workplace relationships, as well as the mechanism of food.
topics: Buddhism, Panchatantra, Bhagwat Gita and Interpersonal Dynamics - Learning Outcomes
Buddhism, Panchatantra, Bhagwat Gita and Interpersonal Dynamics - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Employee Loyalty, Chanakya, and Interpersonal Dynamics
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to the concept of the Flexibility, Quality of Life and Work-Family Enrichment, Employee Loyalty, and Chanakya and Interpersonal Dynamics. You will learn about workplace flexibility and the types of workplace flexibility. You will also learn about the problems organizations face in generating employee loyalty, and the five pillars of Chanakya's aphorisms.
topics: Employee Loyalty, Chanakya, and Interpersonal Dynamics - Learning Outcomes
Employee Loyalty, Chanakya, and Interpersonal Dynamics - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Diploma in Managerial Skills for Interpersonal Dynamics - Second Assessment
modules.description: You must score 80% or more to pass this assessment.
topics: Diploma in Managerial Skills for Interpersonal Dynamics - Second Assessment

modules.name: Module
topics: Diploma in Management Skills for Interpersonal Dynamics - Course Assessment

slides:
• Learning Outcomes
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you will be able to:
    • Discuss the concept of relationship development and maintenance.
    • Identify the characteristics of relationships.
    • Discuss how damaged relationships can be repaired and restored.
    • Explain Knapp's ten stages of a relationship.
    • Identify the dialectical perspectives and tension aspect of relationship building.
    • Discuss the alternate patterns of relational development.
    • Discuss the concept of fundamental interpersonal relationship orientation behaviour (FIRO-B).
    • Identify the types of behaviour.
    • Explain the models of FIRO-B.
  • Why We Form Relationships

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Why We Form Relationships

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Knapp's 10 Stages of a Relationship (I)

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Knapp's 10 Stages of a Relationship (I)

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Alternate Patterns of Relational Development

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Alternate Patterns of Relational Development

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Understanding Relationship Dissolution

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Understanding Relationship Dissolution

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Interpersonal Relations & Types of Behavior

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Interpersonal Relations & Types of Behavior

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Behavior Associated with Inclusion Need (I)

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Behavior Associated with Inclusion Need (I)

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary
    • At the workplace, competence is important, as well as being a great team player. So, there is a need to understand the different skills for developing great relationships at work as well as maintaining the relationship.
    • Dialectical tension occurs when conflict arises between two opposing or incompatible forces simultaneously. Managing dialectical tensions can create the most powerful dynamics in relational communication.
    • Knapp’s stages of relationship development are initializing, experimenting, intensifying, integrating, bonding, differentiating, circumscribing, and stagnating.
    • A manager must have technical, human, conceptual, and design or innovation managerial skills.
    • Relationships are formed based on appearance, similarity, competence, disclosure, proximity, rewards.
    • The word FIRO - Fundamental Interpersonal Relations Orientation is the name of a theory of interpersonal relations introduced in 1958 by the Schutz, first in 1958. Interpersonal relations has been expanded to include all levels of human organizations, including individuals.
    • The two types of behavior are wanted and expressed behavior.
    • Beyond our physiological needs for food and safety, we have some interpersonal needs. This is because we are human beings and people need people. Interpersonal orientation, therefore, refers to individual differences in preference for social interaction. 
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you will be able to:
    • Define the concept of forgiveness.
    • Discuss the models and dimensions of forgiveness.
    • Explain the different roots of the word forgiveness.
    • Discuss the subject-matter of happiness at the workplace.
    • Identify the different factors that affect employees' happiness at work.
    • Explain the theories of happiness.
    • Discuss the key characteristics of workplace happiness.
    • Identify the five critical factors of workplace happiness.
  • Forgiveness: Introduction

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Forgiveness: Introduction

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • A Process Model for Forgiveness (I)

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • A Process Model for Forgiveness (I)

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Introduction, Meaning, and Definition

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Introduction, Meaning, and Definition

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Key Defining Characteristics of Workplace Happiness

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Key Defining Characteristics of Workplace Happiness

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary
    • Forgiveness is an intentional and voluntary process by which a victim undergoes a change in feelings and attitude regarding an offense, and lets go of the negative emotions associated with the offense such as anger and blame, with an increased ability to wish the offender well.
    • Forgiveness is a way for individuals to repair damaged workplace relationships and overcome debilitating thoughts and emotions resulting from the interpersonal injury.
    • The dimensions of forgiveness are forgiveness of self, the forgiveness of others, and forgiveness of situations.
    • The word happiness is derived from the Greek word 'Hap' which means chance or fortune. Happiness is a state of being happy and peaceful.
    • Happiness has two qualitative distinct aspects: one is experienced satisfaction, the other is global satisfaction.
    • Employee happiness is intrinsic so it is under the control of the employee. Employee engagement, on the other hand, is extrinsic as it is largely controlled by the employer.
    • Workplace happiness focuses on the individual experience of human conditions at work. It measures how well an individual experiences the job which supports his psychological well-being and pursuit of happiness.
    • The key defining characteristics of workplace happiness are freedom, knowledge, and religious orientation.
    • The Five Cs of workplace happiness are Contribution, Conviction, Culture, Commitment, and Confidence.
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you will be able to:
    • Discuss the concept of trust.
    • Explain the dimension and models of trust.
    • Identify the architects of trust.
    • Explain the concept and importance of employee recognition.
    • Explain the types and models of employee recognition.
    • Define the concept of psychological ownership.
    • Analyze the dimensions of psychological ownership.
    • Analyze management practices that foster psychological ownership.
  • Trust: Introduction

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Trust: Introduction

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Architect of Trust

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Architect of Trust

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Employee Recognition: Introduction

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Employee Recognition: Introduction

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Engagement and Recognition Models

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Engagement and Recognition Models

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Psychological Ownership: Introduction

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Psychological Ownership: Introduction

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Psychological Ownership Based Job Creation

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Psychological Ownership Based Job Creation

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary
    • Trust is the firm belief in the reliability of a person or thing. It is a state of being relied on, a confident expectation.
    • Under conditions of high trust, problem-solving tends to be creative and productive, while under conditions of low trust, problem-solving tends to be degenerative and ineffective.
    • The architects of trust are authenticity, emotional intelligence, climate building, and walking the talk. 
    • Employee recognition is the timely, informal, or formal acknowledgment of a person's or team's behavior, effort, or business result that supports the organization’s goals and values, and which is clearly beyond expectations.
    • The seven keys to a successful employee recognition program are to recognize frequently, be specific, align with your core values, encourage participation, seek continuous feedback, use technology, and communicate effectively.
    • Psychological ownership is the recognition by an employee or a feeling of an employee of having a stake in the organization as a result of his or her commitment and contribution.
    • Psychological ownership is associated with positive outcomes for the organization, including increased motivation, company stewardship, and employee loyalty.
    • The dimensions of psychological ownership is psychological ownership based on a job creation model, formal ownership, and collective psychological ownership.

  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you will be able to:
    • Define the concept of managerial effectiveness.
    • Identify some basic philosophies of managerial effectiveness.
    • Explain the roles of a manager.
    • Analyze the models of managerial effectiveness.
    • Explain the concept of executive effectiveness.
    • Discuss the origin of servant leadership.
    • Define servant leadership.
    • Discuss servant leadership in the Indian context.
    • Identify the different dimensions of servant leadership.
  • Concept of Managerial Effectiveness

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Concept of Managerial Effectiveness

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Introduction and Definition

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Introduction and Definition

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Concepts of Managerial Effectiveness

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Concepts of Managerial Effectiveness

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Servant Leadership: Origin

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Servant Leadership: Origin

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary
    • Organizations depend on qualified employees who will perform their assigned jobs effectively and efficiently. Employees, therefore, play an imperative role in the aspects of escalation and survival of organizations due to their ability to make decisions and the consequent impact of these decisions.
    • Organizations need effective and competent managers to realize their objectives efficiently and effectively.
    • Managerial effectiveness is the degree to which managers achieve the output requirements corresponding to their respective positions. It is the act of fulfilling multiple expectations rather than optimizing a single objective.
    • The effectiveness of an individual is dependent on so many factors, some of which are personal attributes, competencies, work setup and work culture, forces within and outside the organization, and the organizational psychological climate.
    • A leader is someone who influences the behaviors of others. The origin of servant leadership can be traced back to 375 BC. 
    • Servant leadership consists of serving and developing others, consulting and involving others, humility and selflessness, modeling integrity and authenticity, and, inspiring and influencing others.
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you will be able to:
    • Discuss the concept of affect, emotions, and moods.
    • Explain the functions of emotions.
    • Identify the sources of emotions and moods.
    • Analyze the application of emotions and moods.
    • Discuss the coping strategies for role stress.
    • Explain how managers influence their subordinate's moods.
    • Discuss the various models of moods and emotions.
    • Explain the concept of optimism.
    • Discuss the types and theories of optimism.
    • Analyze the different strategies of becoming optimistic.
    • Explain the outcome of optimism in the workplace.
  • Introduction, Functions, and Sources

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Introduction, Functions, and Sources

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Executive Glow up and Burnout

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Executive Glow up and Burnout

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • The New Model of Moods and Emotions

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • The New Model of Moods and Emotions

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Introduction & Meaning

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Introduction & Meaning

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Introduction & Meaning

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Types of Optimism

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Types of Optimism

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Types of Optimism

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary
    • Affect is the broad range of feelings that people experience. It can be in the form of emotions or moods. The functions of emotion are rationality and evolutionary psychology.
    • Emotions can be generated from the days of the week, the weather, stress, social activities, sleep, or the lack of sleep.  Emotions and moods can be applied on motivating workers, leadership, negotiation, excellent customer service delivery.
    • Frustration is the blocking or slowing down of a goal-directed objective. It is usually caused by privation, deprivation, and conflict.
    • The six types of personality are conventional, realistic, investigative, artistic, social, and enterprise.
    • Manager cans use humor to lighten moods, give a small token of appreciation, lead by example, and hire more positive people.
    • Optimism is the belief that good will ultimately prevail in the world. It is a state of being positive. Optimism is an individual difference variable that reflects the extent to which people hold generalized favorable expectancies about their future.
    • The types of optimism are personal optimism and self-efficacy optimism.
    • Optimism is different from hope and realism.
    • Theories of optimism are the theory of explanatory style and the theory of dispositional optimism. 
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you will be able to:
    • Explain the concept of career engagement.
    • Discuss the human capital theory as it relates to career engagement.
    • Differentiate between career engagement and career management.
    • Analyze why career engagement matters.
    • Explain the wheel of career engagement.
    • Define the concept of adaptability.
    • Analyze the adaptability process in an organization.
    • Explain the antecedents of adaptive performance.
    • Explain the enemies of adaptability.
  • Introduction & Human Capital Theory

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Introduction & Human Capital Theory

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Career Engagement

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Career Engagement

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Adaptability: Introduction

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Adaptability: Introduction

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Antecedents of Adaptive Performance

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Antecedents of Adaptive Performance

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary
    • Career engagement is defined as the emotional and cognitive connection to one's career. The degree to which an individual is proactively unveiling different career behavior. 
    • An individual's career decision often has an impact on his or her career success. 
    • Human capital theory suggests that obtaining a fit between your human capital investment and job requirement generates rewards in terms of higher pay which leads to engagement.
    • There are three wheels of career engagement that helps an individual to evaluate his or her career engagement. 
    • Today, organizations are characterized by a constantly changing and dynamic environment. This, therefore, implies that the need for adaptive workers in the organization is constantly increasing.
    • According to the Centre for Creative Leadership, adaptability can be achieved in three steps. One is through ideas, change, and facts.
    • There are three types of flexibility, and they are Cognitive, Emotional, and Dispositional flexibility.
    • Adaptability is the key function of flexibility. It leads to managerial effectiveness.
